awd_titl_txt: Optical Spin Orientation and Transport in Layered Mono- and Di-Chalcogenide Semiconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical description: Electronic devices for computing logic are traditionally based on the charge of electrons, but as scaling this technology becomes increasingly difficult due to heat and size constraints, new physical systems are necessary for improving logic devices. One possibility to tackle this problem is to utilize an electron's "spin" rather than its charge, which requires less energy and produces less heat. Translating this approach to emerging nano-scale materials is likely to reveal approaches for miniaturized low-power spin-based electronics functioning at the smallest length scales possible. This research focuses on understanding how to orient and transport spin and spin-analogs in nanomaterial systems that harness the advantages of the ultimate atomic-scale limit of single layered crystals. These efforts could have broad impact by making the advantages of layered atomically-thin materials available to spin-based devices, thereby helping to smooth adoption of these exciting materials for nano-scale technologies that surpass the functionality of existing well-understood bulk systems. The supported activities facilitate mentoring of the next generation scientific workforce fluent with the intersection of optics, quantum materials, and nano-science. This research integrates into pedagogical improvements to curriculum that promote scientific interest and enthusiasm for diverse students. 

Technical description: The ability to use light to orient spins and induce spin currents has been a key tool in the study of spintronics in bulk materials. By studying several classes of non-centrosymmetric crystals that are already known to support spin-related phenomena, this research translates the advantages of optical methods used in three-dimensional spintronics to reveal novel effects in low dimensions. Going beyond previous work exploiting light to control spin, this project investigates several unanswered questions, including (i) how optically-excited spin transport evolves over low-dimensional interfaces, and (ii) can the non-centrosymmetric crystals common in two-dimensional materials enhance the ability to control optically-induced information. To address these questions, this research explores spin orientation and transport phenomena using two distinct, but complementary, approaches. The first theme exploits the unique atomic-scale interfacial and heterostructure capabilities of layered van der Waals materials to understand spin-valley currents. This activity aims to measure interface effects of the valley Hall effect in opto-electronic devices. The second thematic direction of this research explores predictions of favorable spin properties in few-layer mono-chalcogenides that suggest suitability of this material class for traditional optical spin orientation methods. This theme aims to measure optically-induced spin dynamics in indium selenide and control transfer of spin polarization between electron and nuclear spin ensembles. Research carried out toward these goals advances understanding of spin transport and optical orientation and expands the tools available for spin manipulation in two-dimensional materials, thereby creating opportunities for highly tailored miniaturized opto-electronics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The aim of this project was to advance understanding of the optical orientation and dynamics of spin in low-dimensional materials and heterostructures. This research sought to translate optical methods of spintronics to two-dimensional (2D) Spin orientation and transport mechanisms are important components of spin-based devices that have been well-understood in traditional spintronics systems, but despite a proliferation of recent work, these methods have often not been systematically explored in 2D materials beyond proof-of-principle demonstrations. materials while harnessing their low-dimensional advantages, specifically in layered heterostructure devices and monochalcogenide materials like InSe. During the course of this research, several novel optical and spin features of low-dimensional heterostructures and layered materials were addressed. Major outcomes of this research are outlined here.

  1. Demonstration of optical orientation of spin polarization in InSe: Optical control for spintronic applications has been pioneered by nanostructures of III-V and II-VI semiconductors. However, layered 2D materials offer a new landscape for optical, electrical, and spin manipulation. In particular, group-III monochalcogenide InSe, a van der Waal material, has been proposed as a promising platform due to its high electron mobility and predictions of near-direct bandgap, spin-dependent optical selection rules, suggesting potential for all-optical control of spin in 2D spin-based devices. To demonstrate key ingredients of spintronics with this material, optical spin orientation was implemented using magneto-photoluminescence and ultrafast pump-probe methods to reveal spin polarization and layer-dependent dynamics. Circularly-polarized excitation was observed to lead to polarized exciton emission at low temperature, confirming that light can orient spin polarization in InSe. In thick crystals, time-resolved Kerr rotation was used to detect spin precession in a magnetic field. These dynamics were characterized by the g-factor, which was measured to be significantly less than the free electron g-factor of 2. To understand this, a layer-dependent model was implemented to predict exciton g-factors. This band approach was supported by density functional theory calculations. These models demonstrate that the precession is likely the result of strongly bound excitons. This work presents the first detailed experimental picture of spin dynamics in InSe layers, demonstrating layer-dependent control over spin properties.
  2. Tunable emission from localized excitons in gate-defined monolayer p–n junctions: The versatile fabrication methods afforded by two-dimensional layered materials nature facilitate integration of layered materials into optoelectronic devices. Using these for all-electrical pumping of quantum light sources in these materials is advantageous to applications in quantum nanophotonics since it enables more compact and scalable devices. In the past, the lack of control of quantum emitter spatial positions and energies has impeded the integration of these 2D material light sources into quantum optical systems. A lateral gate-defined p-n junction was designed in WSe2 to generate single photon electroluminescence in a tunable electrostatic environment that can be tuned in situ. By utilizing local strain engineering, bright localized exciton emitters states were reliably positioned in the optically active region of the gate-defined junction, enabling the deterministic creation of optoelectronic devices with single photon emission. A spectral shift of the electroluminescence is observed, demonstrating the capability for simultaneous electrical pumping and tuning of localized exciton emission in layered quantum opto-electronic devices.

 Broader Impacts: The new understanding of spin phenomena and how to measure them developed in this project can help deliver advances in low-energy electronics suitable for next-generation technologies. This project also created opportunities for mentoring the next generation of students in experimental methods at the intersection of optics, quantum physics, and material science. Specifically, professional development was provided to both graduate and undergraduate researchers participating on the project. The experiments and apparatus were also used to recruit local high school students to participate in summer research before applying to college. Interactions with instrumentation manufacturer Quantum Design led to scientific testing of a brand new magneto-optical cryostat, with key results communicated in a video and used by the vendor to demonstrate the system’s capabilities to the community. Results from this research were disseminated in peer-reviewed journals and conference presentations.
